pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 3: Revolute Joint (plus framework for other joint types)

content.html:
To get a sense for what’s happening, we’ve basically made this possible:

// Cast from a generic joint to a RevoluteJoint
auto revolute = joint->CastToRevoluteJoint();

// Now use the API that is specific to RevoluteJoints,
// like setting the joint axis.
revolute->SetAxis(Eigen::UnitZ());

The Joint class will have a function CastToXXX() for each joint type that the physics plugin supports. If a joint can be casted to the requested type XXX, the user will be given a std::unique_ptr<XXX> (in the future we will switch to std::optional instead of std::unique_ptr). If the joint object that the user attempted to cast could not be converted into the more specific type, then the cast function will return a nullptr (or in the future nullopt). If the cast was valid, then the user can safely start to call on the API of the specific type.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 3: Revolute Joint (plus framework for other joint types)

content.raw: Also note that this `RevoluteJoint` supports both 2D and 3D simulations. Other joint types might be specific to 2D or 3D. For example, `BallJoint` would only make sense in 3D simulation, so we’ll want it to disable itself in a 2D context.
content.html: Also note that this RevoluteJoint supports both 2D and 3D simulations. Other joint types might be specific to 2D or 3D. For example, BallJoint would only make sense in 3D simulation, so we’ll want it to disable itself in a 2D context.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 3: Revolute Joint (plus framework for other joint types)

content.raw: a balljoint would act like a revolute joint in 2d, so maybe that could work, but I think the universal joint wouldn't make sense in 2d since the axes have to be orthogonal
content.html: a balljoint would act like a revolute joint in 2d, so maybe that could work, but I think the universal joint wouldn't make sense in 2d since the axes have to be orthogonal

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 3: Revolute Joint (plus framework for other joint types)

content.raw:
Yeah, this exact line of code only works in specific situations \(like you need to call it in a function scope or when you've already declared `using namespace ignition::physics;`\), so I should make this line more explicit.

I’ve also been stumbling across some inconsistency about when and how exactly this type of aliasing \(overwriting a template name with an alias of the same name\) is allowed, so I might try to look up the exact rules on that.
content.html:
Yeah, this exact line of code only works in specific situations (like you need to call it in a function scope or when you've already declared using namespace ignition::physics;), so I should make this line more explicit.

I’ve also been stumbling across some inconsistency about when and how exactly this type of aliasing (overwriting a template name with an alias of the same name) is allowed, so I might try to look up the exact rules on that.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 3: Revolute Joint (plus framework for other joint types)

content.raw: I don't think ODE or bullet have an API for getting or setting joint acceleration. So we could consider partitioning this into smaller features and making `GetBasicJointState` a feature list instead?
content.html: I don't think ODE or bullet have an API for getting or setting joint acceleration. So we could consider partitioning this into smaller features and making GetBasicJointState a feature list instead?

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 3: Revolute Joint (plus framework for other joint types)

content.raw:
Would an engine-specific wrapper be able to compute and return the joint acceleration for each engine? If so, we wouldn’t need to partition the feature.

That said, I’m not against further granularity. We just need to consider the trade-offs between high granularity and the complexity of keeping track of lots of partitioned features. \(Edit: This also adds to complexity for users, as they try to figure out whether they need to be adding more features on top of whatever we determine the “standard” set should be.\)

Since we’re still in early alpha, I might recommend relatively modest granularity, with the option of decomposing features further as the need arises. Partitioning a feature in the future should have no impact on plugins that are already implementing the feature, as long as we replace the feature with a FeatureList that has the same name and the same virtual functions.
content.html:
Would an engine-specific wrapper be able to compute and return the joint acceleration for each engine? If so, we wouldn’t need to partition the feature.

That said, I’m not against further granularity. We just need to consider the trade-offs between high granularity and the complexity of keeping track of lots of partitioned features. (Edit: This also adds to complexity for users, as they try to figure out whether they need to be adding more features on top of whatever we determine the “standard” set should be.)

Since we’re still in early alpha, I might recommend relatively modest granularity, with the option of decomposing features further as the need arises. Partitioning a feature in the future should have no impact on plugins that are already implementing the feature, as long as we replace the feature with a FeatureList that has the same name and the same virtual functions.

pullrequest.title: Feature System Part 3: Revolute Joint (plus framework for other joint types)

content.raw:
I think the set of engines that make it easy to get joint acceleration is much smaller than the ones that provide `GetPosition` and `GetVelocity` interfaces.

We can punt this until later when we really start testing the abstraction layer with more engines, it just jumped out at me as I was reading the code.
content.html:
I think the set of engines that make it easy to get joint acceleration is much smaller than the ones that provide GetPosition and GetVelocity interfaces.

We can punt this until later when we really start testing the abstraction layer with more engines, it just jumped out at me as I was reading the code.

I'm going to try reproducing it on my local machine
